asked the Minister for Industry and Energy if any consideration has been given to additional grants for small industries in view of the employment potential of small scale enterprises; and if any analysis has been concluded which evaluates their contribution to employment in Ireland during the seventies.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Industry and Energy (Mr. M. O'Leary) Minister for Industry and Energy (Mr. M. O'Leary)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Industry and Energy (Mr. M. O'Leary)
Speaker.P: I am informed by the Industrial Development Authority that grants approved for small industry projects are invariably at higher levels than those given under other IDA grant programmes. In most cases, grants to small industries represent the highest proportion of the overall financial investment in new or expanding industrial projects.

Small industries have available to them the full range of IDA incentives and manufacturing tax reliefs in addition to Euro-currency loans at preferential rates of interest which are provided by the Industrial Credit Company for both working capital and fixed assets.

To ensure the continued growth of the small industry sector, my Department, in conjunction with the Industrial Development Authority, have been carrying out a series of discussions for some time with the county development teams throughout the country to improve the effectiveness of the small industry programme at regional level.

In recent years small firms have played an increasingly important role in our job creation strategy. In 1980 small industry job approvals amounted to about one-third of total job approvals as compared with 12 per cent in 1975.
asked the Minister for Industry and Energy the grants available for private bog development having regard to the importance of turf as an alternative energy source to imported fuels.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Industry and Energy (Mr. M. O'Leary) Minister for Industry and Energy (Mr. M. O'Leary)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Industry and Energy (Mr. M. O'Leary)
Speaker.P: Grant assistance for the development of privately owned bogs, for the production of turf for fuel, is available from Bord na Móna through funds being provided from the Vote for my Department. Owners (or lessees) of bogs, or holders of turbary rights, may apply to the board for grant assistance towards the cost of access roads, bog drainage, including outfall drainage, and the purchase, lease or hire of turf development equipment to be used for or in connection with the bog development.

The scheme provides for a grant of up to 60 per cent in the case of development by a qualified society or a qualified group. A qualified society means a society which is registered under the Industrial and Provident Societies Act, 1893, while a qualified group means an informal and unregistered group of not fewer than three persons who have entered into an agreement to carry out a bog development. In any other case, the amount of the grant will not exceed 45 per cent. Contractors may be given the same level of grants but only in respect of machinery designed or intended by its manufacturer to be used exclusively or principally for the extraction of turf for fuel.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. P. Barry) Peter Barry

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Nuclear Fall-Out Protection Plans.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Brady Mr. G. Brady
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Defence the plans to protect the population in the event of nuclear fallout; and if he will consider the provision of shelters such as those being constructed in several European countries.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Defence (Mr. Tully) James Tully
Speaker.P: My Department's policy for the protection of the population from the effects of radioactive fallout is based on the idea of domestic refuge rooms prepared by householders themselves and on the ability of the Civil Defence organisation to predict and monitor radio-activity and to warn and advise the public in relation to it.

For the levels of radiation which might reasonably be expected here, the mere fact of staying indoors, in itself, provides a significant protection and this protection factor can be very substantially increased by carrying out simple protective measures. Advice to the public in this regard is contained in my Department's booklet “Bás/Beatha” which is available free of charge.

The arrangements for detecting, measuring and predicting radio-activity and for warning and advising the public in relation to it are tested annually by means of the Civil Defence National Fallout Exercise the most recent of which — Network '81 — took place on Sunday, 29 November.

asked the Minister for Agriculture the reason a person (details supplied) in County Offaly has not been allowed grant aid from the 1981 livestock hardship fund scheme in view of the fact that he has 23 reactors out of a herd of 72 cattle.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Dukes) Alan Dukes
Speaker.P: During the period of operation of the 1980-81 hardship fund scheme six qualifying reactors were detected in the herd of the person named by the Deputy. Since this number did not exceed 20 per cent of the basic herd — 78 animals — no grant was payable.

Under the 1981-82 scheme, the basic herd was 71 animals. To date, ten qualifying reactors have come to light and four additional reactors may also qualify. However, qualifying reactors under the 1981-82 scheme would have to exceed 14—20 per cent of the basic herd—before the question of a payment would arise.

asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs if he will initiate discussions with the responsible authorities in Britain with a view to securing the early return of the book The Annals of Innisfallen to a suitable centre in Killarney, County Kerry.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Professor Dooge) James C.I. Dooge
Speaker.P: I understand that title to the original manuscript of The Annals of Innisfallen is vested in the Bodleian Library, Oxford, in whose possession it has been for over 200 years. It would appear therefore that the only way of securing the return of the manuscript to this country would be by purchase. However, I have no reason to think that the Bodleian Library would be willing to sell it.

The Deputy may wish to be aware that there are some 30 manuscript copies of this work in various libraries. The National Library of Ireland hold three copies by different scribes, as well as a microfilm of the original. A facsimile was published by the Dublin Institute for Advanced Studies in 1951.
